coredata.dc:title: Resonant photoemission of solid C60
coredata.dc:creator: Brühwiler, P.A.
Maxwell, A.J.
Nilsson, A.
Whetten, R.L.
Mårtensson, N.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Resonant photoemission spectra of thick films of C60 on a Mo(110) substrate are presented. The data show distinct resonances of the three lowest binding energy photoemission structures, at each of the first four peaks in the C 1s absorption spectrum, thereby indicating significant localization of the excited electron for all of the absorption transitions below the ionization limit. The importance of matrix element effects for an accurate understanding of the intensity variations is stressed.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 193, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 5 June 1992 Resonant photoemission of solid C6o P.A. Briihwiler, A.J. Maxwell, A. Nilsson Department of Physics, Uppsala University, Box 530, S-751 21 Uppsala, Sweden R.L. Whetten Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of California, Los Angeles, CA 90024, USA and N. Mhrtensson Department of Physics, Uppsala University, Box 530, S- 751 21 Uppsala, Sweden Received 2 March 1992 Resonant photoemission spectra of thick films of Cr0 on a Mo(110) substrate are presented. The data show distinct resonances of the three lowest binding energy photoemission structures, at each of the first four peaks in the C 1 s absorption spectrum, thereby indicating significant localization of the excited electron for all of the absorption transitions below the ionization limit. The importance of matrix element effects for an accurate understanding of the intensity variations is stressed. The spherical C6o molecule has attracted enor- mous attention since the discovery of a method [ 1 ] for its production in macroscopic quantities. Among the interesting properties already known are struc- tural phase transitions as the temperature is lowered from room temperature [2, 3] and the ability of films of C6o to superconduct with relatively high transition temperatures when intercalated by alkali metals [4,5 ]. Large efforts are in progress to understand the electronic aspects of these properties (see, e.g., ref. [6]). The electronic structure of solid C60 films has been studied in great detail by a variety of experimental methods, including photoelectron spectroscopy (see, e.g., ref. [ 7 ] ), inverse photoemission [ 8 ], electron energy loss spectroscopy [ 9,10 ], and X-ray absorp- tion [ 11,12 ]. One of the general conclusions at this point is that the electronic spectra of C6o are char- acteristic of nearly isolated molecules, as might be expected from the filled highest occupied molecular Correspondence to: P.A. Briihwiler, Department of Physics, Uppsala University, Box 530, S-751 21 Uppsala, Sweden. orbital (HOMO) and the sizable HOMO-LUMO gap. However, some bonding effects in the form of band dispersion have been deduced from inverse photoemission by comparison to theory [ 8 ], and the effects of neighbor molecules may also have been ob- served via different allowed transitions in optical and electron-based absorption measurements [ 9 ]. Inter- molecular bonding of C6o is expected to proceed via some combination of electron hopping [ 13 ] and van der Waals attraction [ 14]. Electron hopping is a problem which can in principle be studied by core deexcitation processes, as we describe below, and thus is a motivation for the present work. Near a core electron absorption threshold three processes must be considered [ 15,16 ], if we neglect the low-probability soft-X-ray emission events: ( 1 ) Auger decay. The excited electron may leave the core- excited atom and the normal so-called two-hole Au- ger process occurs; (2) Spectator decay. The excited electron remains spatially localized, and the core hole decays in an Auger process modified by the screen- ing effects of this electron; (3) Participator decay. The excited electron remains, and takes part in the 0009-2614/92/$ 05.00 1992 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. All rights reserved. 31 1 Volume 193, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 5 June 1992 annihilation of the core hole, resulting in a sin#e-hole final state. The three processes just named are often collectively termed deexcitation processes [ 15 ]. Participator transitions result in the same final state as normal photoemission, and are often called res- onant photoemission. In this paper, we will focus on the participator de- cays, which are straightforward to identify. A pre- vious study of such resonant processes in C6o found that a strong participator decay of the HOMO occurs at the core-to-bound excitation threshold, and that resonance effects were essentially negligible at higher excitation energies [ 17 ]. This observation was used to conclude that C6o forms extended band-like states. In stark contrast, we find that there are indeed participator resonances at excitation energies above threshold, and that matrix element effects cannot be neglected in the interpretation of the data. As we will show, the data we have acquired are quite detailed, and should in principle yield many useful quantities, like hopping parameters [ 18 ], but require accurate theoretical input in order to make full use of the in- formation contained. In the absence of such theo- retical backup, here we outline what can easily be as- certained from our experimental results. All of the data presented here were taken at MAX- Lab in Lund at Beamline 22 [ 19], which consists of a modified SX700 monochromator and a 200 mm radius photoelectron energy analyzer. The total res- olution varied for different types of measurements, and is stated in the figure captions. Energy calibra- tion was carried out regularly. Once its binding en- ergy had been established, the C6o HOMO served as a very useful calibration for the films studied here, though sample charging was a problem for the thick- est films. For the deexcitation spectra the C 1 s line excited by second order light was employed. Binding energies were checked by measurement of the sam- ple valence region before and after C6o deposition, or by taking a spectrum of a comounted metallic sam- ple right after a C6o valence spectrum, without changing the monochromator or spectrometer set- tings. Absolute energy calibration by measurement of characteristic features using first- and second-or- der light was also carried out, but was not required very often due to the high electron spectrometer sta- bility, such that a measurement of the Fermi thresh- old of a metallic sample served to pinpoint the pho- ton energy. Internal consistency of all of these approaches for the data presented here was excellent, and the high stability of the beam in the MAX-Lab ring allowed extended scans without significant en- ergy shifts. This is confirmed, e.g., by the linear shift of the second-order C ls line in the deexcitation spectra over the entire photon energy range studied, as shown and discussed below. Pure C6o was pre- pared at UCLA as described elsewhere [20]. The preparation chamber base pressure was typically ( 0.8-1.5 ) X 10- ~ o Torr, and the measurement cham- ber pressure was 5.5X 10-~ Torr. C6o films were evaporated from a well-degassed evaporator onto a clean Mo(110) substrate, with outgassing during evaporation of 3X 10-9 Torr for early films, and 2 x 10-io Torr for subsequent films. No sign of con- tamination could be seen in either core level or va- lence electron spectra for any of the films. Fig. 1 a is the valence photoelectron spectrum of a thick C6o film. The binding energy of the HOMO has been found to vary as a function of film thickness and substrate. We find a binding energy of 2.60 +_ 0.05 eV for thick films on Mo (110). The cross sections of the molecular orbitals of C6o vary drastically with photon energy [ 7 ]. This can be seen clearly here by comparing fig. 1 b with fig. I a. We will not dwell on the normal photoemission data, but use them as a reference to the reader regarding our sample quality, and for discussion of the resonant photoemission spectra. In fig. 2 we show the absorption spectrum of a typ- ical film at the C Is threshold and above. This spec- trum resembles in all of its particulars the data of Chen et al. [ 11 ]. We find that the threshold reso- nance occurs at a photon energy of 284.5_ 0.1 eV, consistent with other measurements [10,11,21]. Several constant-initial-state (CIS) scans, for which the electron intensity in a given binding energy win- dow is plotted as a function of photon energy, are also included in fig. 2 and are discussed below. In fig. 3 we show a series of electron spectra ob- tained using photon energies near the C I s threshold, in the form of surface plots of intensity as a function of binding energy and photon energy. These data as individual spectra are similar to fig. lb in informa- tion content, but are presented in this way to illus- trate the intensity variations as a function of photon energy. What is evident in fig. 3 is that a normal pho- 312 Volume 193, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 5 June 1992 c >. .. p- ro 06 0 Electron Spectra (b) hv=284.5 eV (a) hv=110 eV Cls \ 25 20 15 10 5 0 Binding Energy (eV) Fig. 1. (a) Photoelectron spectrum of a thick C6o film at h u = 110 eV, with a total energy resolution of 160 meV. (b) Electron spec- trum at h~,= 284.5 eV, with a total energy resolution of 340 meV. The C I s line excited by second-order light is labelled. toemission spectrum is very weak for excitation energies below the C I s absorption threshold, i.e. see the spectra to the "front" of fig. 3a. This is similar to the pattern for thick benzene films [ 22 ]. As the photon energy approaches 284.5 eV, i.e. moving to- ward the "back" of the fig. 3a, drastic intensity vari- ations occur Much of the strongest variation, that at high binding energy, can be associated directly with the creation of C I s core holes, and their subsequent decay via Auger and spectator transitions. As we show in fig. 2, the absorption as measured by total yield spectroscopy has a very similar shape to a CIS scan at a binding energy ~1 of 40 eV, as expected. What fig. 3a also shows is that the three lowest binding en- ergy peaks of the photoelectron spectrum are seen to virtually emerge from the background in this same energy range, indicating the influence of the excited -i >, o c - ,,,i,, 283 .... I, ,,,l,,,,l,,,,I,,,,i,, ,,I,,,,i, ,,,I,,, ,i,,,,1,,,,i,,,,i .... iiiiI NEXAFS vs. Resonant Photoemission: Comparison to CIS scans "1',,,i .... i,,,,i 284 285 Total Yield I- 1st PES structure (HOMO) / -,C]- 2nd PES structure F -+-- 3rd PES structure -- 40 eV "B.E." ,,,r[,,,,ll,,,l,,,,I .... i,,,,i,,,,i,,,,i,,,,I 286 287 288 289 290 Photon Energy (eV) Fig. 2. Comparison of the total yield spectrum to various CIS scans for a thick film, all normalized to have the same intensity in the first transition. The photon energy resolution was 160 meV for all scans shown. The CIS scans were generated by taking a 0.5 eV-wide window from the electron spectrum at the given photon energy, and integrating it. These curves were generated from a denser data set than shown in fig. 3. electron in the form of participator transitions. This is in agreement with the results for benzene [22 ], though in sever disagreement with the interpretation by Krummacher et al. [ 17 ] of their data. Some localization of a core-excited state can be ex- pected at each of the first four peaks in the absorp- tion spectrum, since those transitions are below the core ionization limit. Fig. 3b and the CIS scans in fig. 2 illustrate that this is indeed the case, as par- "~ The use of a binding energy scale here is inconvenient for the discussion of the (constant kinetic energy) Auger transitions, but is more useful for the present discussion and will be retained throughout. 313 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 5 June 1992 Volume 193, number 5 L~ ! ! 25 20 15 10 5 0 -5 Binding Energy (eV) (b) 284 287 2 4 6 8 10 Photon Energy (eV) Binding Energy (eV) Fig. 3. Surface plot of electron spectra of a thick film as a function of hu, in the neighborhood of the core-to-bound transitions of C6o. Both parts of the figure represent the same data, over different binding energy ranges, and from two perspectives. The energy resolution was 160 meV for the photons, and 300 meV for the electrons, for a total resolution of 340 meV. (a) h v increases into the figure, and the absorption spectrum (fig. 2 ) is roughly reproduced by the intensity variations of the highest-binding energy point shown. (b) Zoom shot of the participator transitions, from the low-binding energy, high-photon energy perspective. Some of the detailed intensity variations elucidated by fig. 2 can be discerned. ticipator transition-induced peaks reappear at each of those core transitions. Remarkably, participator decay persists well above the core excitation thresh- old in C60, compared to benzene for which the par- ticipator transitions vanish away from threshold [221. In attempting to understand the intensity varia- tions of the participator transitions, there are three general considerations: (1) the degree of localiza- tion of the excited electron to the probed molecule, i.e. what is the rate of hopping to neighboring mol- ecules, which is the aspect of the problem concen- 314 Volume 193, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 5 June 1992 trated on by Krummacher et al. [ 17 ]; (2) the degree of localization of the excited electron wavefunction to the core hole; (3) other matrix element consid- erations, such as overlap of particular occupied or- bitals with that of the excited core electron. (2) and (3) can be classified as intramolecular aspects of the problem. Theoretical and/or further experimental input will be required to completely unravel these possibilities in our data, e.g., a measurement ofdeex- citation spectra of C6o in the gas phase. We can already deduce, however, the importance of the intramolecular matrix elements from our data, as follows: The CIS scan with the initial state set to the center of the HOMO band (fig. 2) shows a di- senhanced resonance of the HOMO at the second peak in the absorption, compared to the third peak, consistent in a simple picture with a more rapid transport of the excited core electron away from the molecule being probed. Since calculations [8] in- dicate that this peak corresponds in the ground state of the molecule to more delocalized band-like states, it is tempting to conclude that these participator transition intensity variations with photon energy are easily understood in terms of electron transport. Note, however, that the highest three participator transitions vary in intensity in different ways as a function of which absorption transition is being ex- cited, clearly shown in fig. 2 at the second and third NEXAFS peaks. Some of these intensity variations could be explained as due to spectator decays but that does not affect our arguments, since the electron hopping aspects of those processes are the same as for the participators. A shifting Auger background cannot completely explain the variations. This is an unambiguous sign of the importance of matrix ele- ment considerations in understanding the resonant photoemission of C6o. It is also clear from the present results that the authors of ref. [17 ] have misjudged their data, and have in fact identified the second-or- der C I s line as the HOMO resonance. In conclusion, interesting resonance effects, cor- responding to participator decay processes at and above the C 1 s threshold, have been observed for C6o, whose intensities vary qualitatively with the total ab- sorption probability, but with a significant departure at the second absorption transition. The data show unambiguously that localization of the excited core electron to the probe molecule persists to some de- gree for all absorption transitions below the ioniza- tion limit, and by the different degrees of resonance for different final states at each of the four such tran- sitions indicates that intramolecular matrix element effects are important for their understanding. PAB acknowledges a valuable discussion with S.E. Schnatterly. We are grateful for the able technical as- sistance of L. Bolkeg~d and J.-O. Forsell, and the hospitality of the MAX-Lab staff. This work has been carried out in part within the Swedish Consortium on Clusters and Ultrafine Particles, which is sup- ported by the Swedish Natural Science Research Council and the Swedish National Board for Indus- trial and Technical Development. In conclusion, interesting resonance effects, cor- responding to participator decay processes at and above the C 1 s threshold, have been observed for C6o, whose intensities vary qualitatively with the total ab- sorption probability, but with a significant departure at the second absorption transition. The data show unambiguously that localization of the excited core electron to the probe molecule persists to some de- gree for all absorption transitions below the ioniza- tion limit, and by the different degrees of resonance for different final states at each of the four such tran- sitions indicates that intramolecular matrix element effects are important for their understanding. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Resonant photoemission spectra of thick films of C60 on a Mo(110) substrate are presented. The data show distinct resonances of the three lowest binding energy photoemission structures, at each of the first four peaks in the C 1s absorption spectrum, thereby indicating significant localization of the excited electron for all of the absorption transitions below the ionization limit. The importance of matrix element effects for an accurate understanding of the intensity variations is stressed.
